intro: Acer mono var. subtrifidum, commonly known as the Japanese maple with trifid leaves, is a variant of the Japanese maple (Acer mono) characterized by its uniquely divided foliage. The leaves are trifid, meaning they are split into three distinct lobes, giving the plant a distinctive and ornamental appearance. It is a deciduous tree or shrub native to Japan, often cultivated for its vibrant autumn foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 5–10 meters and prefers well-drained soil and partial shade. Its botanical features make it a popular choice for ornamental gardening and horticultural collections.
